docs.snippet: LEAD: In an effort to find a compromise with the European Community over the sticky issue of farm subsidies, the United States will present a plan in Geneva on Monday that modifies its call for an end to such aid.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In an effort to find a compromise with the European Community over the sticky issue of farm subsidies, the United States will present a plan in Geneva on Monday that modifies its call for an end to such aid.

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: A four-year round of negotiations to liberalize world trade is threatened with collapse as a result of the European Community's failure to accept even a modest plan to reduce farm subsidies, officials from the United States and many other nations...
docs.lead_paragraph: A four-year round of negotiations to liberalize world trade is threatened with collapse as a result of the European Community's failure to accept even a modest plan to reduce farm subsidies, officials from the United States and many other nations say. These officials say the inability of the 12 community nations to agree even among themselves to put forward a modest proposal to cut farm subsidies is making it more and more difficult to complete global trade talks. The deadline for an agreement is less than seven weeks away.

headline.main: Trade Talks Stall on Farm Issues

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: The United States offered drastic across-the-board tariff cuts today at the global trade liberalization talks and called on other negotiators to reciprocate, a person at the meeting said.    This source said that the chief United States delegate,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States offered drastic across-the-board tariff cuts today at the global trade liberalization talks and called on other negotiators to reciprocate, a person at the meeting said. This source said that the chief United States delegate, Warren Lavorel, told a committee meeting that the offer, if fully carried out, would represent a reduction of 43 percent in the average trade-weighted tariff.

docs.snippet: PRESIDENT BUSH and the leaders of Congress have decided to end the bruising battle of the budget, though some right-wing guerrillas have vowed to take to the woods and go on fighting against any tax increases as long as they can hold out. But the...
docs.lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT BUSH and the leaders of Congress have decided to end the bruising battle of the budget, though some right-wing guerrillas have vowed to take to the woods and go on fighting against any tax increases as long as they can hold out. But the President and Congressional leaders have grown increasingly wary of the anger of voters over the inability to reach agreement on governing the nation's finances. And they are worried about the danger that the protracted political warfare poses for the weakened national economy. Legislators who vote for this legislation will do so holding their noses for varying reasons. Some will say it raises gasoline taxes too much, others that it raises them too little to improve conservation and reduce dependence on foreign oil. Some dislike the plan because it hits Medicare too hard, others because it does not hit Medicare and other entitlement programs hard enough. And the plan defers the question of how to reorganize the military budget in light of the reduced Soviet threat and new threats like those in the Middle East.

headline.main: Economic Scene; A Budget Accord None Too Soon

docs.snippet: After years of pushing for an end to nations' restrictions on financial, engineering, communications and other services, Washington is losing some of its enthusiasm for liberalization.    The reason is practical politics -- some United States...
docs.lead_paragraph: After years of pushing for an end to nations' restrictions on financial, engineering, communications and other services, Washington is losing some of its enthusiasm for liberalization. The reason is practical politics -- some United States industries are unhappy about giving up protection and could well have the lobbying muscle to block Congressional approval of any agreement that might emerge from the 105-nation trade talks currently under way in Geneva.

headline.main: U.S. Is Changing Its Tune On Liberalization of Trade

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: European Community leaders said today that Iraq's selective release of foreign hostages would not erode their unity in the Persian Gulf crisis, and they pledged not to negotiate with Baghdad to bring their countrymen home.   The 12 Western European...
docs.lead_paragraph: European Community leaders said today that Iraq's selective release of foreign hostages would not erode their unity in the Persian Gulf crisis, and they pledged not to negotiate with Baghdad to bring their countrymen home. The 12 Western European leaders also seemed to hold out the possibility of eventual military action, saying they were "prepared to consider additional steps" within a United Nations framework if the present economic embargo does not force Iraqi troops out of Kuwait.

headline.main: No Talks on Hostages, European Leaders Vow

byline.original: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Latin America's economic prospects have brightened because governments in the region are relying more on market forces and world competition while reducing the state's role, according to new assessments by the Inter-American Development Bank and...
docs.lead_paragraph: Latin America's economic prospects have brightened because governments in the region are relying more on market forces and world competition while reducing the state's role, according to new assessments by the Inter-American Development Bank and Washington policy makers. The policy changes mean that after a decade of stagnation caused by crushing debt burdens, the groundwork is being laid for freer hemispheric trade, the development bank said in a report released on Sunday.

headline.main: Latin American Economies Given Brighter Assessments

docs.snippet: The European Community's continued failure to agree on a common negotiating position on agriculture has deepened pessimism over whether four years of talks aimed at liberalizing world trade can conclude successfully early next month.    Government...
docs.lead_paragraph: The European Community's continued failure to agree on a common negotiating position on agriculture has deepened pessimism over whether four years of talks aimed at liberalizing world trade can conclude successfully early next month. Government officials from the United States, Japan and developing countries, as well as the European Community, have warned that the collapse of the negotiations could set off a disastrous wave of protectionism that could seriously cripple world trade.

headline.main: Gloomy Outlook for Global Talks on Farm Trade

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: After four years of wrangling in the trade talks and with just four weeks to go, nations are still deadlocked on three crucial areas, jeopardizing the entire round, the head of the GATT trade body said today.    "While we still have everything to...
docs.lead_paragraph: After four years of wrangling in the trade talks and with just four weeks to go, nations are still deadlocked on three crucial areas, jeopardizing the entire round, the head of the GATT trade body said today. "While we still have everything to gain, the risk of losing everything has never been so present," said Arthur Dunkel, director general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

docs.snippet: IN every international political crisis since World War II, the dollar has strengthened -- until now. Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the dollar has fallen sharply. It is no longer the most important safe-haven currency.   The dollar's current...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN every international political crisis since World War II, the dollar has strengthened -- until now. Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the dollar has fallen sharply. It is no longer the most important safe-haven currency. The dollar's current weakness should serve as a warning that in the international competition for capital of the 1990's, the United States risks coming up short. Faced with a tightening of bank credit, the savings and loan crisis and cuts in foreign investment, Washington confronts a critical question: Will sufficient capital be available to finance vigorous growth in the decade ahead?

byline.original: By ROBERT D. HORMATS; Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International, was Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs in the Reagan Administration
